text:
Very interesting. I've recently started running an in-running strategy ( everything prior had been pre-race and small edge/high volume) . I've been getting iro 15%+ vs < tenth of that pre and I thought it was wildly unrealistic and unsustainable. Maybe not.    

Biggest difference though is that without a benchmark to measure EV I'm at the mercy of results which is a novelty. I don't usually care what the cash is so long as the underlying EV is there. 

All good fun though, I was bored to death with pre and in-running has been a nice change.  ..... But it's come about cos I improved/rewrote my results analyser, tested it on some 3year old backtest logs I still had, and it revealed a parameter tweak that made it profitable.  :face_with_rolling_eyes:

elements.text:
Very interesting. I've recently started running an in-running strategy ( everything prior had been pre-race and small edge/high volume) . I've been getting iro 15%+ vs < tenth of that pre and I thought it was wildly unrealistic and unsustainable. Maybe not.    

Biggest difference though is that without a benchmark to measure EV I'm at the mercy of results which is a novelty. I don't usually care what the cash is so long as the underlying EV is there. 

All good fun though, I was bored to death with pre and in-running has been a nice change.  ..... But it's come about cos I improved/rewrote my results analyser, tested it on some 3year old backtest logs I still had, and it revealed a parameter tweak that made it profitable.

text:
Worth just pointing out that the above pertains to TPD. I'd be surprised if you can sustain that using prices only unless your volume is tiny.

As far as having to wait for results; given how many HR markets there are. It's no time at all until your results converge so I don't really see this as a big deal but if you really can't wait then just settle against a different result - like use 1.5 as your "win" point and "settle" backs according to whether a runner goes shorter than that - or whatever's appropriate for your bets. Obvioulsly you have to use implied probability of 0.666 for your "wins" but the maths is simple enough.  Settling at the conclusion is really just settling when BATB == 1, there's no particular reason to limit yourself to that.

elements.text:

text: It's only really useful in certain circumstances, but say you need to analyse the relative performance of two groups of back bets at long odds; if you do that just by using the final result then you'll miss a lot of data because you might be missing out on a lot of bets that nearly won and seeing your results skewed by just a few that made it over the line by a nose. If you pseudo-settle all bets according to whether BATB < 1.2 at any point after your bet matches  then you can capture much richer data and make a better comparison between the groups.

elements.text: It's only really useful in certain circumstances, but say you need to analyse the relative performance of two groups of back bets at long odds; if you do that just by using the final result then you'll miss a lot of data because you might be missing out on a lot of bets that nearly won and seeing your results skewed by just a few that made it over the line by a nose. If you pseudo-settle all bets according to whether BATB < 1.2 at any point after your bet matches  then you can capture much richer data and make a better comparison between the groups.

text: So for example if you're evaluating back bets according to whether they went shorter than 1.2 then with x = 1.2 you just have to count your "wins" as matched stake * (1/x * (matched-odds - 1) - (1 - 1/x)). That accounts for the possibility that your horse can go to 1.2 and still lose. Anything that doesn't go shorter than x is -1 * matched stake. Over time the results will be very similar to your win results, with the difference only being a matter of how you define "going shorter than x".

elements.text: So for example if you're evaluating back bets according to whether they went shorter than 1.2 then with x = 1.2 you just have to count your "wins" as matched stake * (1/x * (matched-odds - 1) - (1 - 1/x)). That accounts for the possibility that your horse can go to 1.2 and still lose. Anything that doesn't go shorter than x is -1 * matched stake. Over time the results will be very similar to your win results, with the difference only being a matter of how you define "going shorter than x".

text: Also worth adding that you don't have to evaluate all your bets at the same point, you can evaluate each bet at any point appropriate to that bet individual bet. So you might want to evaluate bets matched at 100 at 2 whilst you evaluate bets matched at 2 at 1.2 (or whatever) - that's fine it's all good. The only thing that you can't really do is evaluate some bets against the win and others against crossing a price threshold. You have to keep a consistent methodology for what counts as "going shorter than x" and that'll get messed up at 1.01.

elements.text: Also worth adding that you don't have to evaluate all your bets at the same point, you can evaluate each bet at any point appropriate to that bet individual bet. So you might want to evaluate bets matched at 100 at 2 whilst you evaluate bets matched at 2 at 1.2 (or whatever) - that's fine it's all good. The only thing that you can't really do is evaluate some bets against the win and others against crossing a price threshold. You have to keep a consistent methodology for what counts as "going shorter than x" and that'll get messed up at 1.01.

text: Just to add to this - you can also do it the other way round and settle back bets who's price crosses some upper threshold as "losers" with the same methodology, which you might want to do if you were backing at short prices. For example you can pseudo-settle backs matched at 1.1 as losers if they go longer than 10 and in that way catch the near losses with the rest settled as winners.

elements.text: Just to add to this - you can also do it the other way round and settle back bets who's price crosses some upper threshold as "losers" with the same methodology, which you might want to do if you were backing at short prices. For example you can pseudo-settle backs matched at 1.1 as losers if they go longer than 10 and in that way catch the near losses with the rest settled as winners.

text: <@U4H19D1D2> (and maybe <@UGV299K6H>) - you make it sound easy: just identify the negative EV bets and stop placing them. In reality, though, finding a good discriminator between positive and negative EV bets is not so easy. How do you go about this?

elements.text: (and maybe

) - you make it sound easy: just identify the negative EV bets and stop placing them. In reality, though, finding a good discriminator between positive and negative EV bets is not so easy. How do you go about this?

text: With a lot of face rubbing - but basically I look for any variable where I can bin bets according to that variable and see a nice sloping line on a graph when I plot variable against profit. I think the main point for most people though is where you then set the cut-off for that variable in your bet-triggering logic. The temptation is to set it just above the point where profit = 0 because that looks like it will yield the most total profit, I think <@U4H19D1D2> will probably agree that that's not what happens, so when I talk about focusing on margin it's  not just eliminating -ev bets but also low ev bets that leads to the maximum returns.

elements.text: With a lot of face rubbing - but basically I look for any variable where I can bin bets according to that variable and see a nice sloping line on a graph when I plot variable against profit. I think the main point for most people though is where you then set the cut-off for that variable in your bet-triggering logic. The temptation is to set it just above the point where profit = 0 because that looks like it will yield the most total profit, I think
will probably agree that that's not what happens, so when I talk about focusing on margin it's  not just eliminating -ev bets but also low ev bets that leads to the maximum returns.

text: ....so if I were specific to <@UUE6E1LA1> I'd say that since 5% seems low he might be best to focus on how he can move that figure up rather than trying to get more bets on at 5% profit, which in practice might just move everything down to 4%. Since he must be using some sort of variable/signal it may just be a case of moving the cut-off value for that signal up a bit. That might eliminate some marginally profitable bets but over all it will very likely increase his total profit.

text: PL = Margin * size * opportunity. I've always looked to the latter as you get decent samples quickly. And opportunity is probably easier to scale than margin and size. For the same PL I'd rather it be 10k bets/day than 1k.

elements.text: PL = Margin * size * opportunity. I've always looked to the latter as you get decent samples quickly. And opportunity is probably easier to scale than margin and size. For the same PL I'd rather it be 10k bets/day than 1k.

text:
I think my biggest problem is with staking and exposures to be honest and this is why I do get battered on occasion. Model prices change, but it is still a mystery as to how best spread my exposure across the duration of the race (do you go apeshit on value once they are first out of the gate or save some exposure for later for example). This of course is related to staking as I know that for certain points in the race my models perform better than at others. I think if I had a model that was flawless from start to finish in the race life would be easier but thats never likely to happen to me. I've done things similar to <@U4H19D1D2>s chart above where I retrospectively "prune" future bets based on finding parameter ranges on old bet histories which do badly. I do suffer from having too many different strategies running simultaneously and I do not truly understand how they interact with one another (be that positively or negatively)
Maybe I should strip things back a bit and go for lower and more stable returns.

elements.text: I think my biggest problem is with staking and exposures to be honest and this is why I do get battered on occasion. Model prices change, but it is still a mystery as to how best spread my exposure across the duration of the race (do you go apeshit on value once they are first out of the gate or save some exposure for later for example). This of course is related to staking as I know that for certain points in the race my models perform better than at others. I think if I had a model that was flawless from start to finish in the race life would be easier but thats never likely to happen to me. I've done things similar to

s chart above where I retrospectively "prune" future bets based on finding parameter ranges on old bet histories which do badly. I do suffer from having too many different strategies running simultaneously and I do not truly understand how they interact with one another (be that positively or negatively)
Maybe I should strip things back a bit and go for lower and more stable returns.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I think that's what a lot of players look like (I know 'cause they dm me) and it's the essence of the problem that I'm getting at. Without seeing exactly what you're doing one can't be precise but my instinct just looking at what you're saying is that you should probably just rein it all in a bit. Bet where you know you're most profitable at slightly below what you hope is the optimum stake and if you want to try ideas to expand your opportunities then do it very minimally with the smallest stakes, tracking net profit against stake when/if you scale up. It doesn't pay to rush in this game, try stuff out very softly.

elements.text: I think that's what a lot of players look like (I know 'cause they dm me) and it's the essence of the problem that I'm getting at. Without seeing exactly what you're doing one can't be precise but my instinct just looking at what you're saying is that you should probably just rein it all in a bit. Bet where you know you're most profitable at slightly below what you hope is the optimum stake and if you want to try ideas to expand your opportunities then do it very minimally with the smallest stakes, tracking net profit against stake when/if you scale up. It doesn't pay to rush in this game, try stuff out very softly.

text: In general I'm happy with things - profit month on month is pretty consistent for close to 2 years now. I just have certain types of race that I lose on if they are run to a certain profile. Prime example without giving anything away, if there is a favourite around 2-2.5 and that never moves above its BSP at all inplay, then I know I am going to be taking a loss on that race. I just take it on the chin at this point in time.

elements.text: I don't know what to say - my models are based purely on fundamentals and at plenty of stages they will see what it considers to be value. Based on your suggestions though I guess if I want to reduce profit volatility I might want to apply some market based filtering on top of things.

text: Constant (caviated) 0EV isn't a bad thing if there's enough high frequency noise around it.  Tbh I rely on the market being right because I'm not likely to work it out any time soon. EMH is at the root of everything I do.

elements.text: Constant (caviated) 0EV isn't a bad thing if there's enough high frequency noise around it.  Tbh I rely on the market being right because I'm not likely to work it out any time soon. EMH is at the root of everything I do.

text:
<@UUE6E1LA1> You're just looking for something that separates better bets from less good bets, that could be something to do with the way you're analysing the race or it could be something to do with the market conditions, or something else like understanding that your model only out-performs the market at certain stages of the race, anything as long as you can show it with reasonable confidence and it makes sense. Once you've got that in place you can go back and look at your other variables and see if they predict profit, if they don't then you ditch them. That way you can continually drive up your margin without your volume trending towards zero.

I'd have to say that I don't think reducing profit volatility is a goal in itself as it will mostly come down to the odds you're betting at. The better goal is just to drive up margin however you measure it.

<@UEA14GBRR> from my experience going for a lot of bets at low EV pretty much the worst thing you can do in running. You'll get hammered by adverse selection and you'll be continually rigging the market against yourself by not letting value develop where it might otherwise have done.

elements.text:
You're just looking for something that separates better bets from less good bets, that could be something to do with the way you're analysing the race or it could be something to do with the market conditions, or something else like understanding that your model only out-performs the market at certain stages of the race, anything as long as you can show it with reasonable confidence and it makes sense. Once you've got that in place you can go back and look at your other variables and see if they predict profit, if they don't then you ditch them. That way you can continually drive up your margin without your volume trending towards zero.

I'd have to say that I don't think reducing profit volatility is a goal in itself as it will mostly come down to the odds you're betting at. The better goal is just to drive up margin however you measure it.

from my experience going for a lot of bets at low EV pretty much the worst thing you can do in running. You'll get hammered by adverse selection and you'll be continually rigging the market against yourself by not letting value develop where it might otherwise have done.

text: Early days for me @Michael and plenty to learn about it. As I said it's just something naive I found in some old abandoned logs, and if it's OK on that 3yo data and also now on recent data, I thought I'd give it a run out. But I agree controlling liability is tricky when you're banging in offers either side.  I'm the opposite pre, get what you can while you can because there might not be any more later....and I'm guessing your talking about a similar approach.

text: I don't bet pre off, just in running.
